items.title: Optionally disable capitalization: interpret the text with all lowercase words as without names.
items.body:
**CURRENT BEHAVIOR** 

```
#  Example 1

>>> input_text = "foo bar spam eggs"
>>> name = HumanName(input_text)
>>> name.first
foo                          
>>> name.last
eggs                        



#  Example 2

input_text = "this text makes no sense, there are no names here"
name = HumanName(input_text)
>>> name.first
there                          
>>> name.last
this text makes no sense        
```

**EXPECTED BEHAVIOR** 

```
>>> input_text = "good films make your life better"
       # ALL WORDS ARE LOWERCASE = NO NAMES IN THE TEXT !!!
>>> name = HumanName(input_text)
>>> name.first
None
>>> name.last
None
```

items.title: Syntax warning due to comparison of literals using is in Python 3.8
items.body: https://github.com/derek73/python-nameparser/blob/ee8b8e047febd7b64fd97cbc7c717df02eab2950/nameparser/parser.py#L742

items.title: Can't parse correctly `Elder Soares`
items.body:
Hey,

At least Brazil guys has name likes Elder Soares that can't be parsed correctly:
```
>>> from nameparser import HumanName
>>> HumanName('Elder Soares')
<HumanName : [
	title: 'Elder' 
	first: '' 
	middle: '' 
	last: 'Soares' 
	suffix: ''
	nickname: ''
]>
>>> 
```

Example a news article about a guy who's name can't be parsed:

items.title: Parsing a name with hyphen
items.body:
Look like `HumanName` isn't compatibly with a name that contains hyphen.

As I understand in the world it is possibly to have a few different system of them.

For example an article at wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-barrelled_name

Any ideas of possibility to add it here?

items.title: `capitalize` should regenerate `full_name`
items.body:
```
obj = NameParser("UNILEVER LTD")
obj.full_name # "UNILEVER LTD"
obj.capitalize(force=True)
obj.full_name # "UNILEVER LTD" instead of "Unilever Ltd", even though other internal fields have been updated
```

items.title: reliance on sys.stdin which is not always available
items.body:
We just got this exception when being used in a lambda since sys.stdin is None:
```
  File \"/var/task/nameparser/config/__init__.py\", line 95, in add_with_encoding
    encoding = encoding or sys.stdin.encoding or DEFAULT_ENCODING
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'encoding'",
```

perhaps using stdout is better as it's less likely to not be available, or expanding the check for it being None

items.title: Tell parser 'this is not a name' or 'this is never a name'

labels.name: probabilistic
labels.description: Requests for things that would prefer probabilistic approach

items.body:
`>>> names.human_names
[<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'III' 
    middle: 'Briefs of amici curiae urging reversal were filed for the State of Minnesota et al. by Hubert H.' 
    last: 'Humphrey' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>, <HumanName : [
    title: 'Attorney' 
    first: '' 
    middle: '' 
    last: 'General of Minnesota' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''`

I don't see a way to tell the parser that 'III' is *never* going to be a first name, and so should never be parsed as such. I added 'attorney general', 'attorney general of minnesota' and 'Attorney General of Minnesota' as titles, hoping it would automatically pick up on the better choices when I ran it again, but it did not. In the original text, his full name is given, so the parser seems to have assumed it was [last name, first name] instead of [last name, suffix]. And his title at the time was Attorney General, but as you can see, the parser instead made that another human name. 

As for the suffix 'Jr.', that is being presented as the first name or title of the next human name, rather than the suffix of the prior human name. I assume this is because of how it interprets commas. 

If it knew absolutely - or at least in my project, that some suffixes are always only suffixes, and never titles or first names, that would help me a lot. But your code does not seem set up to handle that, and I don't know it well enough to fix it and submit a pull request. 

When it is just "Joe Smith" or "Joe E. Smith", it works perfectly. 

What can be done about these two situations? Any guidance you can give here would be appreciated, and maybe I'll be able to contribute based on what I learn. Thanks.

items.title: Parsing multi-name strings
items.body:
I really wasn't sure how to word this but is there a way to parse names that are formatted as follows:
`Rob And Beth Edmunds`

to output as separate names like:
`["Rob Edmunds", "Beth Edmunds"]`

or does this have to be parsed separately?
Thanks!

items.title: Parsing "Junior" as last name
items.body:
Thanks for your work on this library! Maybe I've found an issue using my own name:

```
In [1]: from nameparser import HumanName

In [2]: HumanName('Flávio Juvenal da Silva Junior')
Out[2]: 
<HumanName : [
	title: '' 
	first: 'Flávio' 
	middle: 'Juvenal' 
	last: 'da Silva Junior' 
	suffix: ''
	nickname: ''
]>

In [3]: HumanName('Flávio Juvenal da Silva Jr')
Out[3]: 
<HumanName : [
	title: '' 
	first: 'Flávio' 
	middle: 'Juvenal' 
	last: 'da Silva' 
	suffix: 'Jr'
	nickname: ''
]>
```

`Jr` works as expected, `Junior` doesn't.
Is that as expected?

items.title: incorrect parsing of Brundridge, Contessa A
items.body:
parsing of 'Brundridge, Contessa A' returns:
first = 'A'
middle = ''
last = 'Brundridge'

items.title: Nickname surrounded by single quotes gets taken as the middle name.
items.body:
Is it not the general notion to surround a nickname in quotes (and put it before the surname)? Or is this possibly a limit of the nameparser?

Here are name examples (not real people):
```
Chatham 'Chip' Frankfort
Helen 'Ellie' Brown
```

items.title: Wrong capitalized letter in Portuguese names
items.body:
First of all, congrats for the great project.

I have found a small issue related to Portuguese names. By running the following code:

```python
from nameparser import HumanName
name = HumanName('joao da silva do amaral de souza')
name.capitalize()
str(name)
```

I get the following result:

`'Joao da Silva Do Amaral de Souza'`

when it should be:

`'Joao da Silva do Amaral de Souza'`

The `d` from `do` should be lowercase.

items.title: Wrong parsing of Portuguese prefix "dos" and Hebrew "ben"
items.body:
parsing of "Rafael Sousa dos Anjos" returns "Anjos" as the surname when the correct case is "dos Anjos".
parsing of "Oren ben Horin" returns "Horin" as the surname when the correct case is "ben Horin".

items.title: Van Nguyen capitalizes to van Nguyen
items.body:
```python
h = HumanName('Van Nguyen')
h.capitalize(force=True)
str(h)  # 'van Nguyen'
```

Do first names ever start with lower case?

items.title: bad parsing
items.body:
full_name = 'Virginia G. Essandoh, J.D. '
output: first name = 'J.D.'

items.title: TypeError: decode() argument 1 must be string, not None
items.body:
Constant.titles.add function doesn't have default encoding so it throws this error.

```python
from nameparser.config import Constants
czconst = Constants()
czconst.titles.add('BA'.encode('utf-8'))
```

items.title: IndexError when parsing 'e and e'
items.body:
```
from nameparser import HumanName
HumanName('e and e')
```

gives:

IndexError                                Traceback (most recent call last)

----> 1 HumanName('e and e')

/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nameparser/parser.pyc in __init__(self, full_name, constants, encoding, string_format)
     79         self.string_format = string_format or self.C.string_format

---> 81         self.full_name = full_name

--> 359         self.parse_full_name()
    360

/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nameparser/parser.pyc in parse_full_name(self)

--> 454             pieces = self.parse_pieces(parts)

items.title: possibly incorrect parsing of "grand"

labels.name: probabilistic
labels.description: Requests for things that would prefer probabilistic approach

items.body:
Just noticed that if I parse "Grand Rounds", it returns:
```python
>>> name
<HumanName : [
	title: 'Grand' 
	first: '' 
	middle: '' 
	last: 'Rounds' 
	suffix: ''
	nickname: ''
]>
```

Kinda odd no?

items.title: {first} {last}, {suffix} is incorrectly recognized as {first}, {title}
items.body:
```
>>> name = "John Smith, Dr."
>>> nameparser.HumanName(name)
<HumanName : [
        title: 'Dr.'
        first: 'John Smith'
        middle: ''
        last: ''
        suffix: ''
        nickname: ''
]>
```
But if I insert a comma, it is recognized as per documentation:
```
>>> name = "John, Smith, Dr."
>>> nameparser.HumanName(name)
<HumanName : [
        title: ''
        first: 'Smith'
        middle: ''
        last: 'John'
        suffix: 'Dr.'
        nickname: ''
]>
```

items.title: incorrect parsing of La Shawn K. Ford
items.body:
two-word first name to train on:

```python
>>> HumanName('La Shawn K. Ford')
<HumanName : [
	title: '' 
	first: 'La Shawn K. Ford' 
	middle: '' 
	last: '' 
	suffix: ''
	nickname: ''
]>
```

items.title: Full set of Italian prefixes
items.body:
Hi, I'm considering whether to use this for some Italian names. The first thing I notice is that the list of prefixes is incomplete for Italian: the full set of derivatives from "di" (preposizioni articolate) is de + il/lo/la/i/gli/le, nowadays with space dropped and "d" uppercased, so that the most common are De, Di, Del, Della, Degli, Dei.

Examples from an ugly list of current names I have (separated by underscores and with the surname first):

```
$ grep -E "(De|Di|Del|Della|Delli|Degli|Dei)$" < list | sed --regexp-extended 's/(.+)_(.+)_([^_]+)$/\3 \1/g' | grep -v _ | sort -u
De Anna
De Anton
De Bartolomeis
De Battisti
De Benedetti
De Benetti
De Bernardi
De Bernardinis

items.title: Emojis are parsed as valid names
items.body:
In latest release:
 "John  Doe ☁️" returns:
first: John
middle: Doe
last: ☁️
https://emojipedia.org/cloud/

Maybe somebody wants emojis for names, but it would be useful to have a config to remove emoji's.

items.title: a few common special cases
items.body:
Sister Souljah -- "Sister" is more of a title than last name.
His Holiness the Dalai Lama -- "His Holiness" -- the two words together is the title.
Bob Jones, composer    
Bob Jones, author
Bob Jones, compositeur -- (French for composer)

Here's the code I used:
```
        name = HumanName('Sister Souljah')
        library_sort_name = u' '.join([name.first, name.middle, name.suffix, name.nickname, name.title])
        if name.last:
            library_sort_name = u''.join([name.last, ", ", library_sort_name])
        print "library_sort_name=%s" % library_sort_name
        
        name = HumanName('His Holiness the Dalai Lama')
        library_sort_name = u' '.join([name.first, name.middle, name.suffix, name.nickname, name.title])
        if name.last:
            library_sort_name = u''.join([name.last, ", ", library_sort_name])
        print "library_sort_name=%s" % library_sort_name
        
        name = HumanName('Bob Jones, author')
        library_sort_name = u' '.join([name.first, name.middle, name.suffix, name.nickname, name.title])
        if name.last:
            library_sort_name = u''.join([name.last, ", ", library_sort_name])
        print "library_sort_name=%s" % library_sort_name
        
        name = HumanName('Bob Jones, compositeur')
        library_sort_name = u' '.join([name.first, name.middle, name.suffix, name.nickname, name.title])
        if name.last:
            library_sort_name = u''.join([name.last, ", ", library_sort_name])
        print "library_sort_name=%s" % library_sort_name

```

items.title: Last names that begin with Mac don't capitalize properly
items.body:
The easy case of this is last names that are four letters long and contain Mac: MACK and MACE end up being capitalized to MacK and MacE.

The more complicated case would be names like MACBETH (should be Macbeth, not MacBeth) and MACARONI (should be Macaroni, not MacAroni). I think this should be solved with a whitelist of last names that should not have the letter after Mac capitalized.

The one that'll give ya a real headache is MACLEAN (could be either MacLean or Maclean).

items.title: JOHN DOE M.D. incorrect suffix
items.body:
This ends up being capitalized to:

`<HumanName : [
	title: ''
	first: 'John'
	middle: ''
	last: 'Doe'
	suffix: 'M.d.'
	nickname: ''
]>`

Note that "M.d." should be "M.D.". Curiously, JOHN DOE MD works fine.

Unable to parse the following name

> > > from nameparser import HumanName
> > > name = HumanName("Claus SchroederVP of");

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/igorsf/venv/downloader/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nameparser/parser.py", line 82, in __init__
    self.full_name = full_name
  File "/home/igorsf/venv/downloader/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nameparser/parser.py", line 348, in full_name
    self.parse_full_name()
  File "/home/igorsf/venv/downloader/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nameparser/parser.py", line 430, in parse_full_name
    pieces = self.parse_pieces(parts)
  File "/home/igorsf/venv/downloader/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nameparser/parser.py", line 579, in parse_pieces
    return self.join_on_conjunctions(output, additional_parts_count)
  File "/home/igorsf/venv/downloader/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nameparser/parser.py", line 672, in join_on_conjunctions

IndexError: pop index out of range

items.title: error on two joiner words
items.body:
If a name contains two joiner words one after another, s.a. "John of the Doe", get:
HumanName:ERROR:parser.py:Couldn't find 'The' in pieces.
error.

items.title: How to remove all titles from title set?
items.body: My data set doesn't have any titles, and I don't want it to get confused by names that appear in the titles set. How can I remove all titles from the titles set?

items.title: Bishop is in the list of titles but could be first name
items.body:
[The docs for titles](http://nameparser.readthedocs.io/en/latest/modules.html#module-nameparser.config.titles) say that `titles`

> Cannot include things that could also be first names, e.g. “dean”. Many of these from wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Title. The parser recognizes chains of these including conjunctions allowing recognition titles like “Deputy Secretary of State”.

"Bishop" is in `titles`, but could also be a first name -  e.g. the former U.S. [Congressman Bishop Perkins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bishop_Perkins).

items.title: 'St.' in surname is parsed as middle
items.body:
The period in "St." seems to break parsing of "St. ___" surnames, with "St." being assigned to `middle`.
Example:

``` python
>>> HumanName('Jill St. John')
<HumanName : [
        title: '' 
        first: 'Jill' 
        middle: 'St.' 
        last: 'John' 
        suffix: ''
        nickname: ''
]>
```

It seems to work properly if the period is removed from "St.", however that is altering how the person spells their name.

This might be caused by a conflict with `HumanName.C.regexes['initial']` which checks for periods
with `r'^(\w\.|[A-Z])?$'` . `HumanName.C.prefixes.add()` also seems to strip trailing '.' , so that's not available as a workaround.

items.title: document that to effectively add to suffixes you have to add to suffix_acronyms
items.body:
So it took me a long time to understand why

nameparser.config.CONSTANTS.suffixes.add('pc') 

was not effective, finally realized by reading the code that

nameparser.config.CONSTANTS.suffix_acronyms.add('pc') 

would be, but it was not obvious.  Maybe add this to the docs.

items.title: Option to get None instead of empty string
items.body:
Hey,

is there an option to get `None` instead of an empty string for the components? E.g.

``` python
>>> name = HumanName("1 & 2, 3 4 5, Mr.")
>>> name.title
None
>>>name.first
'3'
```

items.title: Enhancement request: Support '... Ph. D.' instead of only '... Ph.D.'
items.body:
In 0.3.12:

HumanName('John Smith, Ph.D.') works as expected, but the common misspelling HumanName('John Smith, Ph. D.'), which incorrectly has a space between Ph. and D., now yields 'Ph. D. John Smith'. Personally I would prefer to go back to 0.3.11's behavior, where it left the misspelled title at the end.

items.title: MSc in title makes for some strange behaviour.
items.body:
I am currently trying to parse names with the nameparser which works perfectly fine, except i encounter some errors when trying to parse trailing titles such as MSc.

Here is a small example of what I am trying to do:

``` python
>>> from nameparser import HumanName
>>> HumanName("Dr. med. univ. Margit Popp")
<HumanName : [
    title: 'Dr. med. univ.' 
    first: 'Margit' 
    middle: '' 
    last: 'Popp' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
>>> HumanName("Dr. med. univ. Margit Popp, MSc")
<HumanName : [
    title: 'MSc' 
    first: 'Dr. med. univ. Margit Popp' 
    middle: '' 
    last: '' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
```

The first example works perfectly fine, but as soon as MSc is in the game it doesnt recognize the other titles nor split the name correctly. I have added MSc (as well as med. + univ.) to the CONSTANTS but it doesnt seem to help. It also acts strange when i just use default settings:

``` python
>>> HumanName("Dr. med. univ. Margit Popp, MSc")
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'MSc' 
    middle: '' 
    last: 'Dr. med. univ. Margit Popp' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
```

What i would be expecting is:

``` python
>>> HumanName("Dr. med. univ. Margit Popp, MSc")
<HumanName : [
    title: 'MSc Dr. med. univ.' 
    first: 'Margit' 
    middle: '' 
    last: 'Popp' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
```

I am running python 3.4 with the latest version of nameparser. Is there any possibility of making this work? Am i just missing some customizable setting?

thanks for your help

items.title: nickname getting output at end of name with no punctuation
items.body:
When I parse the name Dr. Jason "Jay" Ross:

```
>>> from nameparser import HumanName
>>> test_name = 'Dr. Jason "Jay" Ross'
>>> test_hn = HumanName( test_name )
```

It is broken out like this:

```
>>> test_hn
<HumanName : [
        title: 'Dr.' 
        first: 'Jason' 
        middle: '' 
        last: 'Ross' 
        suffix: ''
        nickname: 'Jay'
]>
```

When I convert it to a string:

```
>>> str( test_hn )
'Dr. Jason Ross Jay'
```

...the nickname is positioned at the end of the string, so it looks like it is the last name and Ross is the middle name.  In my code, I use the HumanName class as the canonical way to convert from name parts to name string, and that has worked well up until this.  It is wrapped in a method call, and so for now I've just started removing any nickname before I convert to string.  Is there another way to specify how you want the nickname to be treated in string output?

Thanks!

Jon Morgan

items.title: Middle initial 'e.' remains lowercase when using capitalize()
items.body:
Middle initial `e.` will remain lower case after calling `capitalize()`. I am using Python3.4 and nameparser-0.3.10

```
>>> name = HumanName('scott e. werner')
>>> name
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'scott' 
    middle: 'e.' 
    last: 'werner' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
>>> name.capitalize()
>>> name
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'Scott' 
    middle: 'e.' 
    last: 'Werner' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
```

I cannot repeat the bug with the middle initial: `l.`

```
>>> name = HumanName('scott l. werner')
>>> name.capitalize()
>>> name
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'Scott' 
    middle: 'L.' 
    last: 'Werner' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
```

items.title: Inputting Accents causes exception (UnicodeDecodeError)
items.body:
name = HumanName("Beyoncé Knowles")
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 6: ordinal not in range(128)

items.title: 'Co-Chairs' is not detecting as formal title

name = HumanName('Co-Chairs Muffy Miller')
name.first+' '+name.last
u'Co-Chairs Miller'

items.title: V and DVM
items.body:
Both HumanName('Hardie Leannon V') and HumanName('Hardie Leannon DVM') fail, improperly assigning 'V' and 'DVM' to the last name, respectively.

```
>>> HumanName('Hardie Leannon V')
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'Hardie' 
    middle: 'Leannon' 
    last: 'V' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
>>> HumanName('Hardie Leannon DVM')
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'Hardie' 
    middle: 'Leannon' 
    last: 'DVM' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
```

items.title: Can't handle Japanese names
items.body:
> > > name = nameparser.HumanName("鈴木太郎")
> > > 
> > > name
> > > Traceback (most recent call last):
> > >   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
> > > UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 36-39: ordinal not in range(128)

Also: the concept of "last name" and "first name" isn't valid for Chinese, Japanese, Korean (CJK) names.

items.title: San San Chiou
items.body:
> > > from nameparser import HumanName
> > > name = HumanName('San San Chiou')
> > > name
> > > <HumanName : [
> > >     title: '' 
> > >     first: 'San San Chiou' 
> > >     middle: '' 
> > >     last: '' 
> > >     suffix: ''
> > >     nickname: ''
> > > ]>

I expected "San" for first name, "San" for middle name, and "Chiou" for last name.

items.title: Roman Numeral Suffix
items.body:
Roman numeral suffixes get capitalized improperly.

E.g., 

```
>>> h = HumanName("GEORGE SHANAHAN IV")
>>> h.suffix
IV
>>> h.capitalize()
>>> h.suffix
Iv
```

items.title: Smith, J.R.
items.body:
Version = 0.3.4

```
>> nameparser.HumanName('Smith, J.R.')
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'Smith' 
    middle: '' 
    last: '' 
    suffix: 'J.R.'
    nickname: ''
]>
```

Expected would be something which happens when J.R. is split

```
>> nameparser.HumanName('Smith, J. R.')
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'J.' 
    middle: 'R.' 
    last: 'Smith' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
```

Seems to be related to JR.  Other first and second names without space are put to first field:

```
>> nameparser.HumanName('Smith, A.B.')
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'A.B.' 
    middle: '' 
    last: 'Smith' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
```

My first workaround for now is to replace J.R. with J. R., but support of this rare case would be nice.

items.title: Fix last names that are also titles, e.g. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
items.body:
The title is set to 'Dr. King', as if Dr. King were literally a king.
The last name is set to 'Jr.'
The suffix is empty.

`nameparser==0.3.3` in requirements
running inside of Django 1.7 in a virtualenv

items.title: Last Name 'Ma' treated as a suffix
items.body:
``` python
In [1]: HumanName('Andrew Ma')
Out[1]: 
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'Andrew' 
    middle: '' 
    last: 'Ma' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>

In [2]: HumanName('Ma, Andrew')
Out[2]: 
<HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'Andrew' 
    middle: '' 
    last: '' 
    suffix: 'Ma'
    nickname: ''
]>
```

In line 1 the name is correctly parsed.  However in line 2 (when it is listed "last name, first") the Ma is treated as a suffix and there is no last name.  In my opinion, since there is no last name the parser should assume it's a last name and not a suffix.

items.title: Lastname has multiple words
items.body:
J. Garcia de Jalon
lastname = "Garcia de Jalon"
"JUAN DELA CRUZ"
lastname = "DELA CRUZ"

items.title: First name Van (which is also sometimes a prefix) not handled correctly
items.body:
``` python
>>> from nameparser import HumanName
... HumanName('Van Nguyen')
0: <HumanName : [
    title: '' 
    first: 'Van Nguyen' 
    middle: '' 
    last: '' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
>>> import nameparser
>>> nameparser.VERSION
1: (0, 3, 3)
>>>
```

items.title: Multi-part last names following prefix
items.body:
The parser doesn't appear to capture multi-part last names following a prefix, such as 

Pennie von Bergen Wessel

Any strings following a prefix should be classified as a last name, not a middle name as below:

[u'wessels', u'pennie']
{'C': <Constants() instance>,
 'ENCODING': u'utf-8',
 '_full_name': u'pennie von bergen wessels',
 'count': 0,
 'first_list': [u'pennie'],
 'last_list': [u'wessels'],
 'middle_list': [u'von bergen'],
 'nickname_list': [],
 'original': u'pennie von bergen wessels',
 'string_format': None,
 'suffix_list': [],
 'title_list': [],
 'unparsable': False}

items.title: support titles with periods in them, e.g. "Rt.Hon."
items.body: 02d7addefdba18bece5e71655737726edf5287ca removed support for this but seems fixable. I think I just need to only split on periods for titles but not for suffixes, but I'm not sure if that's a true statement or I just think it is because that's the only tests I have. Seems a dubious assumption because there are titles that also appear as suffixes.

items.title: should support for titles that start with a conjunction, e.g. "The Rt Hon"
items.body:
```
$ python tests.py "The Rt Hon John Jones"
<HumanName : [
    title: 'Hon' 
    first: '' 
    middle: '' 
    last: 'John' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>
```

Should be:

```
$ python tests.py "The Rt Hon John Jones"
<HumanName : [
    title: 'The Rt Hon' 
    first: 'John' 
    middle: '' 
    last: 'Jones' 
    suffix: ''
    nickname: ''
]>

```

Fix the test `test_conjunction_before_title()`

Don't break "E Jones"

items.title: Suffix changes
items.body:
```
'do',
'dds',
'dpm',
'dmd',
```

Also, when there are multiple suffixes without commas it gets wonky. 

Ex.
Fname Lname jr., MD --> it'll read jr. as the last name instead of Lname. 

Fname Lname {suffix1}, {suffix2} --> suffix1 becomes the last name.

Not sure how to fix it since the cases I'm speaking of are using only one comma instead of two.

items.title: Make string format handle commas better
items.body:
If you use a formatting string that includes commas, the commas are included in the string output regardless if they are needed. 

```
>>> name = HumanName("John Smith")
>>> name.string_format = "{last}, {title} {first} {middle}, {suffix}"
>>> str(name)
'Smith, John ,'
```

It would be nice if there was a way to only include the commas when they are necessary.

items.title: use regex to recognize roman numeral suffixes
items.body:
Roman numerals that occur after the name are currently recognized by putting the strings in the `SUFFIXES` constant. This works, but the regex below would recognize more variations of roman numbers. 

```
("roman_numeral", re.compile(r'^(XC|XL|L?X{0,3})(IX|IV|V?I{0,3})$', re.I | re.U)),
```

The regex is currently in the `REGEXES` constant but not being used. Since the naming convention is pretty archaic and mostly reserved for kings, probably won't get around to it unless someone would find it useful.

items.title: Running capitalize on a name with multiple suffixes introduces an extra comma
items.body:
If I have a name in the format _last_name_, _first_name_ _suffix-list_, for example: SAHNI, ARU MD PHD, nameparser produces the following:

```
<HumanName : [
    Title: ''
    First: 'ARU'
    Middle: ''
    Last: 'SAHNI'
    Suffix: 'MD, PHD'
    Nickname: ''
]>
```

If I then run capitalize on the name, I get:

```
<HumanName : [
    Title: ''
    First: 'Aru'
    Middle: ''
    Last: 'Sahni'
    Suffix: 'Md,, Phd'
    Nickname: ''
]>
```

Notice the extra comma after the "Md" title. This seems to be due to the fact that the suffix_list is being concatenated with a comma, but being split on whitespace in the capitalize function. I'll submit a pull-request for this shortly.

items.title: Failing names
items.body:
Prime Minister Manmohan Singh
Narendra Modi

items.title: reorganize tests into separate files
items.body: Probably use nose as the test runner.

items.title: Update documentation using sphinx

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Reimplement configuration to make it easier to change the constants. Use ``unicode_literals`` for Python 2 & 3 support.

items.body: Update the project documentation using sphinx and publish to readthedocs.org

items.title: Judge-related titles not parsing

milestone.description: Add special case for first names and titles, update constants

items.body:
Hey -

First off, awesome package. I've been working with a dataset of ~3000 judges and associated titles, and noticed nameparser doesn't pick most (well, any) of them up. Below is the filtered list with at least a few examples/variations on each. I'm happy to do the changes if you'd like. Let me know.
# common

Magistrate Judge John F. Forster, Jr
Magistrate Judge Joaquin V.E. Manibusan, Jr
Magistrate-Judge Elizabeth Todd Campbell
Mag-Judge Harwell G Davis, III
Mag. Judge Byron G. Cudmore
Chief Judge J. Leon Holmes
Chief Judge Sharon Lovelace Blackburn
Judge James M. Moody
Judge G. Thomas Eisele
Judge Callie V. S. Granade
Judge C Lynwood Smith, Jr
Senior Judge Charles R. Butler, Jr
Senior Judge Harold D. Vietor
Senior Judge Virgil Pittman  
Honorable Terry F. Moorer
Honorable W. Harold Albritton, III
Honorable Judge W. Harold Albritton, III
Honorable Judge Terry F. Moorer
Honorable Judge Susan Russ Walker
Hon. Marian W. Payson
Hon. Charles J. Siragusa
# rare

US Magistrate Judge T Michael Putnam
Designated Judge David A. Ezra
Sr US District Judge Richard G Kopf

items.title: Allow Suffixes to be chained
items.body:
"QC MP" is a common title for members of the UK parliament. When a multiple suffixes come at the end of a name they should all be counted as suffixes (or titles, #2) regardless of commas.

Example names:

"The Rt Hon Kenneth Clarke QC MP, HMG"
" FREUNDEL J. STUART Q.C. M.P.."

items.title: Parsing title and last name, e.g. "Mr XXX" should be last name, not first name

milestone.description: Add special case for first names and titles, update constants

items.body:
Love this library - very useful. 

However, I've noticed that parsing names in the format Prefix Lastname (e.g. Mr Magoo) parse with a blank name.last and the last name in the first name position (e.g. name.first == Magoo, name.last == ''). I think this should be the other way round!

I may have time to fix this in your code later, but for now i'm using the following kludge to make it work in my code...

if name.title != '':
        if name.last == '':
            name.last = name.first
            name.first = ''

items.title: Can't install on Python 3
items.body:
I got this error while i'm trying to install on my Python3 enviroment. I'm a novice on programming so if you may point it out what i'm doing wrong.
angel@angel-K72Jr:~/development/nameparser-0.2.7$ sudo python3.2 setup.py install
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 6, in <module>
    import nameparser
  File "/home/angel/development/nameparser-0.2.7/nameparser/**init**.py", line 8, in <module>
    from parser import HumanName
ImportError: cannot import name HumanName

items.title: Use from __future__ import unicode_literals

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Reimplement configuration to make it easier to change the constants. Use ``unicode_literals`` for Python 2 & 3 support.

items.body:
I only recently became aware of `unicode_literals` support from python 3. Conceptually it seems all of the parsers files should import than and then we could remove the unicode markers `u""` from the strings. But that unicode marker was rewritten by @corbinbs his implementation of python 3 support. I'd need to take a deeper look and make sure I know what I'm doing first. Any suggestions or advice welcome.

I think this will also make it run on Python 3.2. Currently the tests raise a syntax error on `return u''` from `lc()`.

items.title: Suffix not capitalized when all upper case
items.body:
https://code.google.com/p/python-nameparser/issues/detail?id=22

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. from nameparser import HumanName
2. k = HumanName("WOOT ALFRED DOUGHERTY III")
3. k.capitalize()

What is the expected output? What do you see instead?
Expected :

```
<HumanName : [
        Title: '' 
        First: 'Woot' 
        Middle: 'Alfred' 
        Last: 'Dougherty' 
        Suffix: 'III'
]>
```

Output that I see instead :

```
<HumanName : [
        Title: '' 
        First: 'Woot' 
        Middle: 'Alfred' 
        Last: 'Dougherty' 
        Suffix: 'Iii'
]>
```

This seemed to work. 

```
>>> k = HumanName(("WOOT ALFRED DOUGHERTY III").lower())
>>> k.capitalize()
>>> k
<HumanName : [
        Title: '' 
        First: 'Woot' 
        Middle: 'Alfred' 
        Last: 'Dougherty' 
        Suffix: 'III'
]>
```

items.title: Suffix not parse correctly in format "last_name Jr., first_name"
items.body:
https://code.google.com/p/python-nameparser/issues/detail?id=30

What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. HumanName("John Smith Jr.")
2. HumanName("Smith Jr., John")
3.

What is the expected output? 

```
<HumanName : [
    Title: '' 
    First: 'John' 
    Middle: '' 
    Last: 'Smith' 
    Suffix: 'Jr.'
]>
```

What do you see instead?

```
<HumanName : [
    Title: '' 
    First: 'John' 
    Middle: '' 
    Last: 'Smith Jr.' 
    Suffix: ''
]>
```

What version of the product are you using? On what operating system?
0.2.7, Python 2.7, Windows 7

items.title: Ph.D., Esq., M.D., C.F.P., etc. are titles, not suffixes

labels.name: probabilistic
labels.description: Requests for things that would prefer probabilistic approach

items.body:
Moving [the previous issue](https://code.google.com/p/python-nameparser/issues/detail?id=7) from the Google Code because I like the idea and would like to implement it, someday. Originally posted by jayqhacker, Feb 7, 2012.

---

Ph.D., Esq., M.D. and other titles are classified as suffixes.  This is perhaps convenient for parsing, since they appear at the end of a name, but they are in fact titles.  A suffix distinguishes people and is part of your legal name; a title does not and (in most countries) is not.  "J. Smith Jr." and "J. Smith Sr." are certainly different people, whereas "J. Smith", "J. Smith, PhD" and "J. Smith, MD" may or may not be.

I propose titles end up in the .title field, and suffices end up in the .suffix field.

Name parsing is a hard problem; ultimately I think you'd want a statistical, machine learning approach, but you can probably get pretty far with rules.

The two issues are: 1) some suffixes are part of your name, some aren't; and 2) some titles come before your name, some after. 

You could solve both by splitting titles into pre- and post-titles, and making suffixes just `('jr','sr','2','i','ii','iii','iv','v')`.

---

Project Member #3 derek73

I played with adding a new list to keep track of titles that were added at the end. If we treat the suffixes as a definitive and complete list, then we can assume anything else is a title. The initials "i" and "v" are problematic, but we could probably assume that they are initials in the case of "John V". 

I like the idea of separating out the parts of the name that definitely signify another person, and your definition of suffix. Thinking about it, I guess a suffix always comes directly after the name? Like you wouldn't have "John Doe, Phd, Jr". Also the case of having 2 suffixes seems somewhat remote, e.g. "'Smith, John E, III, Jr'"? So I guess that would make the patterns look something like this.

```
# no commas:      title first middle middle middle last suffix|title_suffix title_suffix
# suffix comma:   title first middle last, suffix|title_suffix [, title_suffix]
# lastname comma: last, title first middles[,] suffix|title_suffix [,title_suffix]

SUFFIXES = set((
    'jr','sr','2','i','ii','iii','iv','v',
))

TITLE_SUFFIXES = set((
    'phd','md','esquire','esq','clu','chfc','cfp',
))
```

I got as far as finding that equality test would need to be updated. It got me wondering if perhaps we should change the equality test, per your example, to test that ' '.join(first, middle, last, suffix) are the same. Perhaps its easy enough for someone to test if unicode() representations are equal on their own if they want titles too. Or maybe that's too smart.

---

That sounds like a reasonable approach.  I don't personally use equality, but you might consider having it do the "dumb" least-surprise exact comparison, and adding a similarity method that returns a float in 0.0 - 1.0, eventually aiming for something like the probability that these two names reference the same person.

Also, watch out for "King John V."  ;)

items.title: make the constants more easily configurable

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Reimplement configuration to make it easier to change the constants. Use ``unicode_literals`` for Python 2 & 3 support.

items.body:
Make it easier to adjust the constants for your own purposes. We know we're never going to be perfect for everyone so it should be more easy and obvious how to customize handling. Something like:

```
HumanName.constants.titles.add('Dean')
```

Currently the regex for things like initials and nicknames are in constants.py and there's no easy way to change them. Should make the regex configurable too.
